@graph.description: The heterodimeric kinesin-2 motor (KIF3A/KIF3B with accessory protein KAP3) drives intraflagellar transport, essential for ciliogenesis and ciliary function. Three point mutations in the KIF3B subunit have recently been linked to disease in humans (E250Q and L523P) and Bengal cats (A334T) (Cogné et al., 2020). Patients display retinal atrophy and, in some cases, other ciliopathy phenotypes. However, the molecular mechanism leading to disease is currently unknown. Here, we used Kif3a-/-;Kif3b-/- (knockout) 3T3 cells, which cannot make cilia, to characterize these mutations. While reexpression of KIF3B(E250Q) and KIF3B(L523P) did not rescue ciliogenesis, reexpression of wildtype or KIF3B(A334T), restored ciliogenesis to wildtype levels. Fluorescent tagging revealed that the E250Q mutant decorated microtubules and thus is a rigor mutation. The L523P mutation, in the alpha-helical stalk domain, surprisingly did not affect formation of the KIF3A/KIF3B/KAP3 complex but instead impaired motility along microtubules. Lastly, expression of the A334T motor was reduced in comparison to all other conditions and displayed an impaired ability to disperse the Golgi complex when artificially linked to this high-load cargo. In summary, this work uses cell-based assays to elucidates the molecular effects of disease-causing mutations in the KIF3B subunit on the kinesin-2 holoenzyme.
keywords: cell biology, primary cilium, intraflagellar transport, motor protein mutation, KIF3B, ciliopathy
@graph.name: Characterization of the Disease-Causing Mechanism of KIF3B Mutations from Ciliopathy Patients

@graph.description: Fixed and mounted cells were imaged on the SP8 microscope using a scanning speed of 400 Hz, pinhole set to 1AU, and a white light laser power of 70%. For the blue channel, the 405 nm laser line was used at 15.7% output power, and the image was collected in the 420-466 nm range using a PMT (gain 631.5, offset 0).  For the green channel, the 487 nm laser line was used between 8.9-15.8% output power, and the image was collected in the 502-552 nm range using a HyD (gain 116.8, offset 0). For the infrared channel, the 647 nm laser line was used at 1.1% output power, and the image was collected in the 662-704 nm range using a HyD (gain 51.3, offset 0).
@graph.labEquipment: Leica SP8 inverted confocal microscope equipped with a 63x, 1.4 NA PlanApo oil immersion objective and one PMT and two HyD detectors. A white light laser in conjunction with an acousto-optic tunable filter (AOTF; Leica) was used for illumination.
@graph.name: Confocal Microscopy

@graph.description: The developed film was imaged with a standard office scanner at 600 dpi.
@graph.labEquipment: Autoradiography film was developed with a Futura Classic E (Fischer Industries Inc) instrument.
@graph.name: Western Blot development

@graph.description: Beads were suspended in 25 µL Lysis Buffer and loaded into flow chambers prepared by attaching clean #1 coverslips (VWR Cat#112614-9) to microscope slides using two layers of double-sided adhesive tape (Tesa Cat# 05338). Beads were identified using brightfield and then imaged in the brightfield, blue, green and red channels. Exposure was optimized for the greatest dynamic range possible for each channel separately and then kept constant throughout the imaging session. The 2.83 megapixels monochrome CCD camera chip was used to collect 14-bit TIF images using no pixel binning (Keyence setting: "high resolution").
@graph.labEquipment: BZ-X810 epifluorescence microscope (Keyence) equipped with a PlanFluor 10x objective with 0.30 numerical aperture (NA) objective and three Chroma filter cubes: blue (Cat# 49028), green (Cat# 49308), and red ("mCherry").
@graph.name: Epifluorescence Microscopy of Agarose Beads

@graph.description: Fixed and mounted specimens were imaged on the BZ-X810 microscope. Transfected cells were located in the green channel and expression in the red channel was confirmed when applicable. Exposure was optimized for the greatest dynamic range possible for each channel separately and then kept constant throughout the imaging session. For Figures 1 and 2, the presence of cilia was evaluated in the red (acetylated tubulin staining) and/or infrared channel (ARL13B staining). If cilia were present, cilia were used for focusing, else focusing was done in the channel in which transfected cells had been selected. For Figure 4, the Golgi apparatus was visualized in the infrared channel (GOLGB1 staining). All cells were imaged in the blue channel (DAPI staining) to visualize nuclei. The 2.83 megapixels monochrome CCD camera chip was used to collect 14-bit TIF images using no pixel binning (Keyence setting: "high resolution").
@graph.labEquipment: BZ-X810 epifluorescence microscope (Keyence) equipped with a Plan Apochromate 40x, 0.95 numerical aperture (NA) objective, and four Chroma filter cubes: blue (Cat# 49028), green (Cat# 49308), red ("mCherry"), and infrared (Cat# 49009).
@graph.name: Epifluorescence Microscopy of fixed cells
